Catalytic transfer hydrogenation using glycerol (GLY) as a hydrogen donor presents a sustainable and secure approach for hydrogenation of quinoline and its derivatives. Conventional non-noble metal catalysts can effectively catalyze the transfer hydrogenation reaction with GLY. However, it is inevitable that metal leaching occurs under alkaline hydrothermal conditions. In this work, N-doped carbon encapsulated non-noble metal catalysts, such as Co@NC, Ni@NC, and CoNi@NC, were prepared by one-pot method combined with an acid leaching for this reaction. According to Mott-Schottky effect, encapsulating of Co, Ni, and CoNi nanoparticles with relatively smaller work function in NC shells constructed a rectifying contact and increased the electron density on NC shells. Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations confirm that electrons transfer from metal cores to NC shell, with CoNi transferring the most, followed by Co and Ni. As a result, the catalytic activity followed the order of CoNi@NC＞Co@NC＞Ni@NC, where CoNi@NC exhibited highest catalytic activity, 92.2% GLY conversion and full quinoline conversion can be obtained over CoNi@NC at 180 °C with 89.7% and 99.3% of the selectivity to lactic acid and 1, 2, 3, 4-tetrahydroquinoline, respectively. In addition, CoNi@NC possessed excellent stability because NC shells physically isolate metal cores from the reactive environment. Such Mott-Schottky catalyst tuning could be an efficient way to design new non-noble catalysts. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Transfer hydrogenation Quinolines Glycerol Encapsulated catalysts Mott-Schottky effect Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Catalytic hydrogenation is of tremendous importance in academic research and the chemical industry [1]. It is an essential step for the reductive transformation of chemicals and the development of new organic molecules [2]. However, the hydrogenation process normally required high-pressure fossil-derived H2 with high capital costs and unfavorable safety risks, often leading to over hydrogenated products [3]. Thus, catalytic transfer hydrogenation using alcohols, formic acid (FA), hydrazine and ammonia borane (AB), as the hydrogen donors has attracted great interest from more and more researchers [4–11]. The selective hydrogenation of quinoline and its derivatives is a fascinating chemical transformation because one of the hydrogenated products, 1, 2, 3, 4-tetrahydroquinoline (py-THQ), is widely used in the preparation of pharmaceutical intermediates, pesticides, and dyes [12,13]. Yun, et al. used AB as the hydrogen donor for the hydrogenation of quinoline and excellent catalytic activity and selectivity to py-THQ can be obtained over nitrogen-rich porous carbon stabilized NiCo catalysts [14]. Huang, et al. demonstrated that excellent catalytic activity of Co single atom catalysts (Co/SNC) in transfer hydrogenation of quinoline to py-THQ with FA as the hydrogen donor [15]. Among all the hydrogen donors, GLY, the main byproduct of the transesterification process in biodiesel production, could be the best because it is currently facing an oversupply problem on the market and can be converted into high-value lactic acid (LA) [16,17]. However, the transfer hydrogenation of quinoline with GLY as the hydrogen donor has been rarely reported. Recently, Dong, et al. used GLY as the hydrogen donor to reduce bicarbonate over PdPt alloy catalysts, 85.4% of GLY conversion with 67.3% yield of LA and 56.5% yield of FA can be obtained at 200 °C [18]. Tang, et al. used cyclohexene as the hydrogen acceptor for the dehydrogenation of GLY to LA over Pt/ZrO2 prepared by an atomic trapping method and an unsurpassed 95% yield of LA at 96% GLY conversion can be achieved at 160 °C with NaOH as the promotor [19]. To reduce the cost, the same research group demonstrated Ni-Co/CeO2 can effectively catalyze the transfer hydrogenation from GLY to obtain a high yield of LA by varying the hydrogen acceptors, but the metal leaching caused the gradual loss of catalytic activity under alkaline hydrothermal conditions [20]. Alternatively, Li, et al. used Co nanoparticles (NPs) encapsulated in ordered mesoporous N-doped carbon (Co@OMNC) for the transfer hydrogenation of quinoline with FA as the hydrogen donor, 98.8% conversion of quinoline with 100% selectivity to py-THQ can be achieved. It was found that the OMNC shells, induced by the cobalt cores, are the new catalytically active centers for both FA dehydrogenation and quinoline hydrogenation and can prevent cobalt NPs from poisoning or leaching [21]. Our group also prepared N-doped carbon embedded Ni catalysts (Ni@NC) for transfer hydrogenolysis of lignin β-O-4 model compounds using isopropanol as the hydrogen source [22]. Mechanical studies revealed that Ni NPs could donate electrons to outer shells, leading to the surface electron enrichment, thus making inert shells catalytically active. The electron transfer from Co/Ni to NC shells in Co@OMNC and Ni@NC is actually caused by the Mott-Schottky effect in solid-state physics [23]. Specifically, when Co/Ni cores with smaller work functions were closely encapsulated by p-type semiconducting NC shells, the electrons would transfer from them to NC shells until their Fermi levels reached equilibrium. The formed Schottky barrier will lead to the electron redistribution within Co@OMNC and Ni@NC and enrich the electrons on NC shells, making them catalytically active for transfer hydrogenation reactions [24,25]. According to the band theory of solids, the surface electron transfer in these heterostructures is strongly affected by the work functions of the metal cores and NC shells [26]. If non-noble metals with different work functions are used as the core, a varying number of electrons may be transferred from the metal core to the NC shells. There is a possibility to modulate the catalytic activity of N-doped carbon encapsulated non-noble metal catalysts (NNM@NC) in the transfer hydrogenation of quinoline with GLY. Considering the work function of the CoNi alloy is smaller than that of either Co or Ni, in this work, Co@NC, Ni@NC, and CoNi@NC (NNM@NC) were prepared by one-pot method combined with an acid leaching procedure. The obtained catalysts were characterized by various techniques, such as N2 sorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The energy bands of NNM@NC were determined by DFT calculations and ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS) measurements. The relationship between the electron density on NC shells affected by the Mott- Schottky effect and the catalytic activity of NNM@NC was further studied by DFT calculations to understand the catalytic process. Meanwhile, the reaction conditions were optimized, and the transfer hydrogenation of quinoline derivatives was investigated. This work demonstrated the possibility of the non-noble Mott-Schottky catalysts for the transfer hydrogenation reaction using GLY as the hydrogen donor under basic conditions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation N-doped carbon encapsulated Co, Ni, and CoNi NPs (Co@NC, Ni@NC,and CoNi@NC) were synthesized by a one-pot method combined with an acid leaching procedure based on our previous work with minor modification [22]. Briefly, 1.0 g poly(ethylene glycol) (PEG, MW = 6000) and 2.0 g of dicyandiamide (DCDA) were first dissolved in a mixture of ethanol (20.0 g) and deionized (DI) water (10.0 g). Then, a total 6.0 g of the metal precursors (6.0 g of cobalt nitrate hexahydrate for Co@NC, 6.0 g of nickel nitrate hexahydrate for Ni@NC, and 3.0 g of nickel nitrate hexahydrate and 3.0 g of cobalt nitrate hexahydrate for CoNi@NC) and 5.0 g of resol ethanol solution (20 wt%) were added to the above solution. After stirring for 0.5 h, the final solution was put into a drying oven at 50 °C for 6 h, followed by 100 °C for 24 h. The obtained composites were calcined in a tubular furnace under N2 at 800 °C for 3 h with a heating rate of 3 °C/min. After that, the calcined samples were leached in 1 M H2SO4 at 80 °C for 12 h, and 1 M HNO3 at 80 °C for another 12 h to remove the unstable metal species, and then washed with D.I. water till the pH = 7. 2.2 Catalyst characterization TEM images were recorded by using Thermo Scientific Talos F200S. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was carried out with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å) operating at 40 kV and 40 mA on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer. Raman spectra were performed with a 514.5 nm argon ion laser (Rhenishaw Instruments, England). XPS and UPS spectra were measured on a Thermo Scientific Escalab 250Xi. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were obtained at − 196 °C using Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. To measure the metal loadings in the catalysts, a certain amount of catalysts was heated in a tubular furnace under O2 at 700 °C for 1 h. After cooling down, the obtained solids were digested in aqua regia (HCl/HNO3 =3:1) at 373 K for 6 h and then diluted with deionized water to a certain volume before analysis by the Thermo Fisher iCAP 7600 series inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES). 2.3 Catalytic activity evaluation The transfer hydrogenation reactions were carried out in a 50 mL stainless steel microreactor. The predetermined amounts of the catalyst with a 20 mL aqueous solution containing appropriate amounts of GLY, quinolines, and NaOH were loaded into reactor. The reactor was then sealed, purged with high purity N2 gas three times, and then charged with N2 to 3.0 MPa. After the reaction ﬁnished, the catalysts were separated by a magnet and then washed several times with ethanol for further use. Subsequently, the solution was extracted with ethyl acetate three times. The products were qualitatively determined by gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC-MS, Shimadzu QP2010 ULTRA) with a HP-5 MS column and quantified with an Agilent 7890B GC with an FID detector and a HP-5 column, the remained aqueous solution were analyzed by high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) equipped with an Aminex HPX-87 H column (Bio-Rad Laboratories), ultraviolet (210 nm) and refractive index (RI) detector. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The TEM image of CoNi@NC in Fig. 1(a) shows that the spherical-like NPs are evenly distributed on the NC skeleton with the mean size of 8.6 nm, as shown in Fig. S2. Upon magnification in Fig. 1(b), it can be observed that the NPs are encapsulated by a few of graphitic carbon layers forming core-shell like structures, which is favorable for increasing the stability and avoiding unexpected reaction since the graphitic carbon layer could physically isolate the NPs from the reactive environment. During the synthesis, the metal salts aggregate to nucleate CoNi alloy NPs with the protection of PEG, then NPs act as the catalytic active sites for the formation of N-doped graphitic layers since such metal alloy NPs can catalyze the small molecules, generated by the decomposition of resol and dicyandiamide, to form CNTs [27]. In addition, some voids can be observed due to the removal of NPs, which are not well encapsulated by the acid leaching procedure. The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image in Fig. 1(c) exhibits that the polycrystalline Co/Ni lattices and graphitic carbon fringes. The nanoparticle has a lattice spacing of 0.203 nm, corresponding to the (111) facet of metallic CoNi [28,29]. Elemental mapping of CoNi@NC in Fig. 1(d) confirm the N elements are homogeneously dispersed in the whole carbon skeleton in Fig. 1(e), while Co and Ni elements are primarily distributed on bright metal NPs in Fig. 1(f and g) to form CoNi NPs. Co@NC and Ni@NC were also prepared using the same method. Their TEM images in Fig. S1 indicated that they also contained metal NPs encapsulated by graphitic NC shells, possessing very similar structures to that of CoNi@NC. The mean sizes for Co@NC and Ni@NC are 10.6 nm and 10.5 nm, respectively, as shown in Fig. S2. Fig. 2(a) shows that the XRD pattern of NC exhibits two peaks at around 24.5° and 43.4°, which can be assigned to the (002) and (100) planes of graphite. When metal salts were added into this one-pot synthesis, the XRD patterns of Co@NC and Ni@NC confirm that metallic Co or Ni NPs were formed with diffraction peaks due to the (111), (200) and (220) planes of the face-centered cubic (fcc) structure of Co (PDF# 15–0806) or Ni (PDF# 04–0850), suggesting the Co or Ni salts can be directly reduced to its metallic state without oxidation after high temperature carbonization process [30,31]. Furthermore, the XRD curve of CoNi@NC also show similar diffraction pattern to those of Co@NC or Ni@NC due to the uniform crystal structures. These three diffraction peaks of CoNi@NC are centered at 44.5°, 51.8°, 76.3°, which are located between the peak position of Co@NC and Ni@NC, further indicating that CoNi alloy NPs are formed [32]. The sizes of Co, Ni, and CoNi NPs calculated based on Scherrer equation in Co@NC, Ni@NC, and CoNi@NC are around 13.0 nm, 12.8 nm, and 10.7 nm, respectively, which are in consistent with the above TEM results. In addition, the diffraction peak due to the (002) planes of graphite in NNM@NC become much stronger and sharper compared to that of NC, indicating the metal NPs promote the formation of graphitic carbon shells, leading to their higher graphitization degree. Raman spectroscopy was performed to study the property of carbon of NC, Co@NC, Ni@NC, and CoNi@NC. Raman spectra of all these samples showed in Fig. 2(b) comprise two peaks located at around 1340 cm−1 and 1575 cm−1, which are attributed to the D band and G band of graphite, respectively. The D band to G band intensity ratio (ID/IG) can be used an indicator for the degree of graphitization of carbonaceous materials [33]. The ID/IG values of NC, Co@NC, Ni@NC, and CoNi@NC are estimated to be 1.01, 0.95, 0.96, and 0.90, respectively. The lower ID/IG values of NNM@NC relative to that for NC imply enhanced graphitization with less defects catalyzed by Co/Ni upon high temperature pyrolysis, which is matched with the intensified diffraction peak of the (002) planes of graphite in NNM@NC. The enhanced graphitization leads to high conductivity of carbon materials, which is beneficial for electrons transfer within NNM@NC. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore size distribution curves of NC, Co@NC, Ni@NC, and CoNi@NC are displayed in Fig. 3(a). The isotherms for these samples are type IV curves with an H1-type hysteresis loop, which is the characteristic of typical mesoporous materials. It can be seen from Table S1 that the specific surface area of NC is 557.0 m2/g, then significantly decreases to 276.8 m2 /g, 268.7 m2/g, and 262.1 m2/g, for Co@NC, Ni@NC, and CoNi@NC, respectively, but the pore volume increases from 0.42 cm3/g to 0.61–0.75 cm3/g for NNM@NC. The Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore size distributions further confirm that a large and broad pore, which is larger than 10 nm, exists in these samples. The porous structures with high specific surface areas increase the number of exposed active sites in NNM@NC, which also greatly increase the mass transfer of reactants and decrease the electron transfer resistance. In addition, as listed in Table S1, the metal loadings of Co@NC and Ni@NC measured by ICP-OES were 13.36 wt% and 15.45 wt%, respectively. For CoNi@NC, the total metal loading is 14.33 wt% and the molar ratio of Co and Ni is 1:1, which are in agreement with the amount of metal precursors added in the synthesis. High resolution XPS measurements were conducted to further understand the chemical states of various elements in NC, Co@NC, Ni@NC, and CoNi@NC. The spectra of Co 2p for Co@NC and CoNi@NC in Fig. 3(b) shows that all the Co 2p3/2 species can be deconvoluted into three peaks at 777.7–778.7 eV and 781.1–781.3 eV due to the metallic Co and ionic Coδ+, respectively, as well as the satellite peak at 784.2–784.6 eV. Similarly, the spectra of Ni 2p for Ni@NC and CoNi@NC in Fig. 3(c) also comprises three peaks at 853.2–852.6 eV, 854.8–854.4 eV, and around 859.6 eV, which are corresponded to the metallic Ni, ionic Niδ+, and the oscillating satellites, respectively. The presence of the ionic state of Co and Ni could be due to the coordination between Co/Ni atoms and N atoms or incomplete reduction of Co and Ni salts during the high temperature carbonization process [21,27,34]. Besides, the peak at 853.2 eV due to metallic Ni in Ni@NC is negatively shifted to 852.6 eV in CoNi@NC, and the peak at 777.7 eV due to metallic Co in Co@NC is positively shifted to 778.7 eV in CoNi@NC, implying the partial electron transfer from Co to Ni, because the electronegativity of Ni is higher than that of Co [35]. The XPS N 1 s spectra of NC and CoNi@NC are shown in Fig. 3(d), it was found that the N 1 s spectrum for NC could be deconvoluted into four peaks at around 398.6 eV, 400.1 eV, 401.2 eV, and 404.1 eV, corresponding to pyridinic-N, pyrrolic-N, graphitic-N, and oxidized-N, respectively, and the content of N species is 7.89 at% as listed in Table S1. For CoNi@NC, the content of N species dropped to 4.13 at% due to the partial removal of the N species, especially the nonstable pyridinic- and pyrrolic-N, under high temperature pyrolysis in presence of Co and Ni [36]. As a result, graphitic-N become the major N species in CoNi@NC. Furthermore, its high-resolution N 1 s spectrum show five peaks that correlate with oxidized N (404.3 eV), graphitic N (401.2 eV), pyrrolic N (400.0 eV), metal-N (M-N) (399.1 eV), and pyridinic N (398.4 eV) [27,37]. The presence of M-N species confirms the coordination between Co/Ni atoms and N species. In addition, the contents of N species in Table S1 also decreased to 4.57 wt% and 3.92 wt% in Co@NC and Ni@NC, respectively. In order to understand the electronic properties of NNM@NC, the work functions of Co, Ni, and CoNi are calculated by DFT calculations (details in Supporting Information) and the work functions of NC, Co@NC, Ni@NC, and CoNi@NC were determined by UPS in Fig. S3. According to the energy band diagrams drawn in Fig. 4, the work functions of Ni, Co, and CoNi are calculated to be 5.41 eV, 5.06 eV, and 4.98 eV, respectively, all of which are smaller than that of NC (6.07 eV), thus generating a Schottky barrier upon the rectifying contact between metal cores and the semiconducting NC shells due to Mott-Schottky effect. As a result, the electrons will spontaneously transfer from metal cores to NC shells until their Fermi levels reach equilibrium, resulting in the electron redistribution within NNM@NC. To further confirm it, we constructed periodic structures using three-layer Co (111), Ni (111), and Co0.5Ni0.5 (111) with a p (3 ×3) supercell, along with a nitrogen-doped graphene layer consisting of 71 carbon atoms and one graphitic nitrogen atom [38,39]. As shown in Fig. S4, the electron density on NC shells in Co@NC, Ni@NC, and CoNi@NC is enriched compared to pure NC due to the electron transfer from metal cores to NC shells. Based on the population analysis of the stable structures, the number of transferred electrons was calculated to be 0.39 a.u., 1.39 a.u., and 1.46 a.u. within Ni@NC, Co@NC, and CoNi@NC, respectively, as listed in Table S2. 3.2 Catalytic activity evaluation The catalytic transfer hydrogenation of quinoline using GLY as the hydrogen donor was evaluated over NC, Co@NC, Ni@NC, and CoNi@NC. It can be seen from Table 1 that NC showed no catalytic activity towards this reaction in aqueous alkaline solution at 180 °C under 3.0 MPa N2 (Entry 1), due to the absence of metal cores. When Co@NC, Ni@NC, and CoNi@NC were used as the catalysts, they all can efficiently catalyze this reaction (Entry 2–4), suggesting the metal cores are vital for catalyzing this transfer hydrogenation. CoNi@NC exhibited the best catalytic activity among these catalysts. Compared with the catalytic results in the hydrogenation of quinoline over noble and non-noble catalysts with different hydrogen sources in the literature (Table S4), not only full conversion of quinoline with 99.3% selectivity to py-THQ can be achieved at 180 °C, but also high value-added LA was obtained with 89.7% selectivity at 92.2% conversion of GLY (Entry 4). The formation of LA in this transfer hydrogenation reaction is attributed to the presence of NaOH, which deprotonates the hydroxyl group of GLY to initiate the dehydrogenation and acts as a catalyst for the subsequent isomerization of the dehydrogenation products of GLY, such as glyceraldehyde (GLYD) and dihydroxyacetone (DHA), into LA [20,40]. Glyceric acid (GLA), glycolic acid (GLYCA) and 1, 2- propanediol (PDO) were observed as the major byproducts, GLA is formed by the dehydrogenation of GLYD, GLYCA is probably derived from the C-C bond cleavage of GLA, and PDO is the hydrogenated product from pyruvaldehyde (PAL), which is produced via the dehydration of GLYD followed by keto-enol tautomerism of 2-hydroxyacetone (HDA) [41,42]. Besides, trace amount of acetic acid (AA) was also obtained by the degradation of LA [43]. In this work, the unencapsulated metal particles were removed by an acid leaching procedure in NNM@NC. The large size GLY molecules cannot diffuse into the inner metal cores, thus NC shells could be the catalytically active sites for this reaction. However, metal-Nx coordinated species also have the possibility to act as the active sites for the hydrogenation and transfer hydrogenation reaction [44–47]. Thus, to identify the catalytically active sites, we carried out the poisoning test with KSCN involved in the reaction, as SCN- ions have strong affinity to metal cations, which can deactivate the metal centered active sites [48,49]. It can be seen from Entry 5 in Table 1 that only slight loss of catalytic activity can be observed on CoNi@NC after KSCN (17 equiv. relative to both Co and Ni) was added into the reaction system, suggesting that NC shells rather than either the metal cores or the Co/Ni-Nx coordinated species act as the active sites for the dehydrogenation of GLY and hydrogenation of quinoline. We also conducted elemental analysis on CoNi@NC after reaction involving with KSCN by using TEM EDX elemental mapping. It can be found from Fig. S5 that the S element is mainly distributed on the NC matrix, indicating that SCN- ions are adsorbed on NC shells rather than the CoNi cores. To further understand the Mott-Schottky effect on the catalytic activity of NNM@NC, we calculated the dehydrogenation of GLY in this transfer hydrogenation reaction by the linear synchronous transit/quadratic synchronous transit (LST/QST) method based on the above models of NNM@NC [50]. It was found in Fig. S6 that the GLY molecule tends to adsorb on the carbon atoms adjacent to the graphitic N atom on NC shells through the H atom in the -OH group. The adsorption energies of GLY on NC, Ni@NC, Co@NC, and CoNi@NC listed in Table S2 are − 0.2802 eV, − 0.2834 eV, − 0.3682 eV, and − 0.4843 eV, respectively, and the energy barriers for GLY dehydrogenation shown in Fig. 5(a) are 0.9232 eV, 0.5210 eV, 0.4721 eV, and 0.4623 eV, respectively. It can be concluded that the more the transferred electrons from metal cores to NC shells, the more stable the adsorption of GLY on NNM@NC, and the lower the energy barrier for GLY dehydrogenation [51]. Thus, GLY is most easily dehydrogenated on CoNi@NC, followed by Co@Ni and Ni@NC, which is consistent with the above catalytic results. Furthermore, the in situ generated H atoms from the dehydrogenation of GLY are also adsorbed on the carbon atoms adjacent to the graphitic N atom on NC shells as shown in Fig. S6, with the adsorption energies of − 1.073 eV, − 2.020 eV, − 2.673 eV, and − 2.737 eV on NC, Ni@NC, Co@NC, and CoNi@NC, respectively. Moreover, the transition state energy barriers for 2 H* → H2 on NC, Ni@NC, Co@NC, and CoNi@NC are 0.1231 eV, − 0.5624 eV, − 0.5733 eV, and − 0.5764 eV, respectively. It is suggested that the electron transfer increased the electron density on NC shells, enhancing the adsorption and desorption of the in situ generated H atoms on NNM@NC. We also investigated the quinoline hydrogenation on NNM@NC. The energy barriers for the quinoline hydrogenation in Table S3 on NC, Ni@NC, Co@NC, and CoNi@NC are 0.1213 eV, − 1.536 eV, − 1.674 eV, and − 1.724 eV, respectively, indicating that the quinoline hydrogenation reaction was also most readily to occur on CoNi@NC. In addition, it can be observed from Fig. 5(b), Fig. S6, Table S2, and Table S3 that quinoline has a planar structure and tends to form hydrogen bonds with the in-situ generated hydrogen atom from GLY on CoNi@NC, thus the energy barrier for the hydrogenation of quinoline to py-THQ is 0.164 eV lower than that for quinoline to 5, 6, 7, 8-tetrahydroquinoline (bz-THQ), which can explain why CoNi@NC is highly selective for the transfer hydrogenation of quinoline to py-THQ. The role of NaOH in the reaction was further studied over CoNi@NC by varying the molar ratio of NaOH and GLY in Fig. 6(a). In the absence of NaOH, the conversion of GLY was only 2.3%, suggesting that NaOH is crucial for the dehydrogenation of GLY. When NaOH was added to reach the molar ratio of NaOH/GLY = 1, the conversions of GLY and quinoline rapidly increased to 78.3% and 88.1%, respectively. However, the selectivity to LA is only 72.6%, suggesting the amount of NaOH is inadequate to promote the formation of LA. Further increasing the molar ratio of NaOH/GLY to 2, although the conversion of GLY increased from 92.2% at the molar ratio of NaOH/GLY to 1.5 to 98.1%, the selectivity of LA reduced from 89.7% to 79.3%. In the meantime, the selectivity to AA raised and formic acid (FA), which originated from the degradation of AA, appeared in the reaction mixture, indicating that a high molar ratio of NaOH/GLY promoted the degradation of LA [52]. Thus, the molar ratio of NaOH/GLY = 1.5 is the optimum value for this transfer hydrogenation over CoNi@NC. Since H species used for the quinoline hydrogenation are in situ generated from the dehydrogenation of GLY, the molar ratio of GLY/quinoline is essential for this transfer hydrogenation reaction. As shown in Fig. 6(b), if the molar ratio of GLY/quinoline was 2, which suggesting that the amount of the generated H species can hydrogenate all the quinoline to py-THQ theoretically. However, the conversion of quinoline is only 82.4% over CoNi@NC, indicating that not all the H species from GLY can be used for the quinoline hydrogenation. When the molar ratio of GLY/quinoline was raised to 3, although the conversion of quinoline is also 100%, the selectivity to LA reduced from 89.7% at the molar ratio of GLY/quinoline = 2.5 to 79.2%, probably because the reaction intermediates can also be hydrogenated by the generated H species. The reaction profile as a function of the reaction time was also explored over CoNi@NC. It is found in Fig. 6(c) that the conversions of GLY and quinoline increased progressively with the reaction time and full conversion of quinoline can be achieved at 6 h of reaction time. In the meantime, the selectivity to LA also increased from 67.1% at 1 h to 89.7% at 6 h of reaction time. However, further prolonging the reaction time to 8 h, it slightly drops to 85.3% due to the degradation of LA. The effects of reaction temperature were also studied over CoNi@NC. As shown in Fig. 6(d), when the reaction was conducted at 160 °C, the conversion of GLY is only 62.8%, because the hydrogen species generated from the dehydrogenation GLY were not enough so that the quinoline hydrogenation was hydrogen starved, leading to low conversion of quinoline. When the reaction temperature is raised to 200 °C, the selectivity to LA decreased from 89.7% at 180 °C to 83.3%, probably due to the formation of the undesired byproducts or the degradation of LA. From the above experiments, it can be seen that the selectivity to py-THQ can always be maintained at around 99% under varying reaction conditions, such as molar ratios of NaOH/GLY and GLY/quinoline, reaction temperature, and reaction time, demonstrating that CoNi@NC is highly selective for transfer hydrogenation of quinoline with GLY. Based on the optimized reaction conditions, a series of quinoline derivatives were chosen as substrates to explore the potential applicability of CoNi@NC in this transfer hydrogenation reaction. As shown in Table 2, the introduction of one more nitrogen atom in the pyridine ring of quinoline almost has no effect on the catalytic activity of CoNi@NC (Entry 1, Table 2). Moreover, quinoline substituted with other functional groups, such as methyl, chloro, bromo, hydroxyl, and methoxy, can be converted to their corresponding py-THQ with full conversion and excellent selectivity (Entry 2–7, Table 2). Especially, the quinoline substituted by halogen groups (Entry 4 and 5, Table 2) can be hydrogenated to the corresponding halo-substituted py-THQ without any dehalogenation. It is suggested that CoNi@NC has excellent catalytic activity and selectivity in the transfer hydrogenation of functionalized quinoline with electro-withdrawing or electron-donating groups [53,54]. The catalytic cycling experiments were also conducted on CoNi@NC to examine its stability in transfer hydrogenation of quinoline with GLY. After the each run of the reaction, CoNi@NC was separated by a magnet and then washed several times with ethanol and dried at 120 °C under vacuum oven. As shown in Fig. 7, CoNi@NC shows no sign of deactivation during five consecutive catalytic runs. The elemental analysis of the reused catalyst shows no Co or Ni leaching in the reaction solution, indicating that NC shells can effectively prevent the metal leaching under alkaline hydrothermal conditions. XRD and TEM characterization in Fig. S7 confirmed that no noticeable changes can be observed between fresh and spent CoNi@NC. All these above results suggest that CoNi@NC possesses excellent catalytic stability and reusability. 4 Conclusion In this work, Co@NC, Ni@NC, and CoNi@NC were prepared by a one-pot method combined with an acid leaching procedure and used for the transfer hydrogenation of quinolines with GLY. DFT calculations and UPS measurements indicated that Ni, Co, and CoNi exhibited reduced work functions, all of which were smaller than that of NC shells, resulting in the spontaneous electron transfer from metal cores to NC shells due to Mott-Schottky effect. DFT calculations further confirmed that the number of electrons transferred from metal cores to NC shells was 0.39 a.u., 1.39 a.u., and 1.46 a.u. for Ni@NC, Co@NC, and CoNi@NC, respectively, which makes NC shells electron enriched. As a result, the increased electron density enhanced the adsorption/desorption of reactants and reaction intermediates on NC shells, leading to the high catalytic activity. The catalytic experiments revealed that their catalytic activity followed the order of CoNi@NC＞Co@NC＞Ni@NC, which is linearly correlated with the number of transferred electrons. Moreover, py-THQ is more favored as the product than bz-THQ as quinoline with a planar structure tends to adsorb vertically on CoNi@NC. In addition, CoNi@NC also showed high catalytic stability during consecutive catalytic runs due to NC shells preventing metal leaching under alkaline hydrothermal conditions. The excellent catalytic activity of CoNi@NC may pave the way for designing highly active and reusable non-noble metal catalysts for transfer hydrogenation of more challenging molecules by using GLY as the hydrogen donor. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic transfer hydrogenation using glycerol (GLY) as a hydrogen donor presents a sustainable and secure approach for hydrogenation of quinoline and its derivatives. Conventional non-noble metal catalysts can effectively catalyze the transfer hydrogenation reaction with GLY. However, it is inevitable that metal leaching occurs under alkaline hydrothermal conditions. In this work, N-doped carbon encapsulated non-noble metal catalysts, such as Co@NC, Ni@NC, and CoNi@NC, were prepared by one-pot method combined with an acid leaching for this reaction. According to Mott-Schottky effect, encapsulating of Co, Ni, and CoNi nanoparticles with relatively smaller work function in NC shells constructed a rectifying contact and increased the electron density on NC shells. Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations confirm that electrons transfer from metal cores to NC shell, with CoNi transferring the most, followed by Co and Ni. As a result, the catalytic activity followed the order of CoNi@NC＞Co@NC＞Ni@NC, where CoNi@NC exhibited highest catalytic activity, 92.2% GLY conversion and full quinoline conversion can be obtained over CoNi@NC at 180 °C with 89.7% and 99.3% of the selectivity to lactic acid and 1, 2, 3, 4-tetrahydroquinoline, respectively. In addition, CoNi@NC possessed excellent stability because NC shells physically isolate metal cores from the reactive environment. Such Mott-Schottky catalyst tuning could be an efficient way to design new non-noble catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Transfer hydrogenation of quinolines with glycerol over N-doped carbon encapsulated non-noble metal catalysts: Mott-Schottky effect on the catalytic activity
